canonical_explanation.text: Probability is a measure of the chance that an event will occur. In Class 9, we study experimental (empirical) probability, where probability is determined from actual trials or observations. Experimental probability of an event E = (number of trials in which E occurred) / (total number of trials). The probability of any event lies between 0 and 1 (inclusive). P(E) + P(not E) = 1. As the number of trials increases, the experimental probability approaches the theoretical probability.
rules: P(E) = (number of trials with favourable outcome) / (total number of trials)
Experimental probability is based on actual observations/experiments
As the number of trials increases, experimental probability approaches theoretical probability

questions.question_text: Experimental probability is based on:
questions.explanation_correct: Experimental (empirical) probability is determined by performing actual experiments or collecting data from observations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Experimental probability comes from real trials/observations, not theoretical calculations.

questions.question_text: The experimental probability of an event E is:

options.text: Number of trials / Number of favourable outcomes
Number of favourable outcomes / Total number of trials
Total trials x Number of outcomes

questions.explanation_correct: P(E) = Number of trials where event E occurred / Total number of trials.

questions.question_text: The probability of any event lies between:
questions.explanation_correct: For any event E, 0 <= P(E) <= 1. Probability is always between 0 and 1 inclusive.

questions.question_text: The probability of a sure event is:
questions.explanation_correct: A sure event always occurs, so P(sure event) = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A certain/sure event has probability 1 (it always happens).

questions.question_text: The probability of an impossible event is:
questions.explanation_correct: An impossible event never occurs, so P(impossible event) = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An event that can never happen has probability 0.

questions.question_text: P(E) + P(not E) = 1 for any event E.
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of the probability of an event and the probability of it not occurring is always 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(E) + P(E') = 1 is a fundamental rule of probability.

questions.question_text: A coin is tossed 100 times and heads appeared 45 times. The experimental probability of getting heads is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(heads) = number of heads / total tosses = 45/100 = 0.45.

questions.question_text: A die is thrown 60 times and the number 4 appeared 12 times. The experimental probability of getting 4 is:
If a coin is tossed 200 times and tails appear 110 times, the experimental probability of tails is ___ (as a decimal).
If P(E) = 0.3, then P(not E) is:
Experimental probability is also called:
questions.explanation_correct: Experimental probability is also known as empirical probability because it is based on observations from experiments.

questions.question_text: In a survey of 50 families, 20 have exactly one child. The experimental probability that a family has exactly one child is:
The probability of an event can be negative.
questions.explanation_correct: Probability is always between 0 and 1 inclusive. It can never be negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0 <= P(E) <= 1 for any event. Negative probability is not possible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT true about experimental probability?

options.text: It is based on actual experiments
It may differ from theoretical probability
It depends on the number of trials

questions.explanation_correct: Experimental probability gives approximate values that depend on the trials conducted. Different experiments may give different probabilities for the same event.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Experimental probability is an estimate based on data, not an exact mathematical value.

questions.question_text: A bag has some balls. 500 balls are drawn one by one with replacement. Red balls appear 200 times. The experimental probability of drawing a red ball is:
If P(raining tomorrow) = 0.65, then P(not raining tomorrow) = ___.
questions.explanation_correct: P(not raining) = 1 - P(raining) = 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

questions.question_text: A doctor records that out of 40 patients with a certain disease, 36 recovered. The experimental probability of recovery is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(recovery) = 36/40 = 9/10 = 0.9. Both B and C express the same value.

questions.question_text: If a coin is tossed 10 times and heads appears 7 times, the experimental probability of heads is 0.7.
The sum of probabilities of all possible outcomes of an experiment is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of probabilities of all possible outcomes always equals 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All outcomes together cover the entire sample space, so their probabilities sum to 1.

questions.question_text: As the number of trials increases, the experimental probability:
questions.explanation_correct: By the law of large numbers, as trials increase, experimental probability gets closer to the theoretical probability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: More trials lead to better estimates that converge toward the theoretical probability.

questions.question_text: In 1000 throws of a die, the outcomes are: 1(180), 2(150), 3(160), 4(170), 5(150), 6(190). The experimental probability of getting an even number is:
A coin is tossed 1000 times. Heads appears 530 times. The experimental probability of getting tails is:
If P(winning) = 0.08, the probability of not winning is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(not winning) = 1 - 0.08 = 0.92.

questions.question_text: A factory inspects 500 items and finds 25 defective. The experimental probability that a randomly selected item is non-defective is:
questions.explanation_correct: Non-defective items = 500 - 25 = 475. P(non-defective) = 475/500 = 0.95.

questions.question_text: Out of 90 days, it rained on 15 days. The experimental probability that it does NOT rain on a given day is ___ (as a fraction in simplest form).
In a cricket match, a batsman hits a boundary 8 times out of 40 balls. The experimental probability of not hitting a boundary is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(boundary) = 8/40 = 0.2. P(not boundary) = 1 - 0.2 = 0.8.

questions.question_text: A spinner has 3 outcomes: Red, Blue, Green. If P(Red) = 0.4 and P(Blue) = 0.35, then P(Green) is:
A coin is tossed 80 times. The number of times it lands on heads is 50. If tossed one more time, the experimental probability of getting tails based on the existing data is:
questions.explanation_correct: Based on existing data: P(tails) = (80-50)/80 = 30/80 = 3/8 = 0.375.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(tails) = 30/80 = 3/8. The experimental probability is based on already collected data.

questions.question_text: Two different experimenters tossing the same coin 100 times each will always get the same experimental probability for heads.
questions.explanation_correct: Experimental probability varies between different experiments. Two people might get different numbers of heads (say 48 and 53), giving different experimental probabilities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Experimental probability is based on actual results, which vary from experiment to experiment.

questions.question_text: A class has 40 students. 28 students passed a test. The experimental probability that a randomly chosen student failed is:
The probabilities of three events A, B, C are P(A) = 1/3, P(B) = 1/4, P(C) = 1/6. If A, B, C are the only outcomes, their sum is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(A) + P(B) + P(C) = 1/3 + 1/4 + 1/6 = 4/12 + 3/12 + 2/12 = 9/12 = 3/4. Since this is not 1, there must be other outcomes too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum = 1/3 + 1/4 + 1/6 = (4+3+2)/12 = 9/12 = 3/4. Since sum is not 1, there are other possible outcomes.

questions.question_text: In a bag, the experimental probability of drawing a blue ball is 0.35. If 200 draws are made with replacement, the expected number of times a blue ball is drawn is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Expected frequency = probability x total trials = 0.35 x 200 = 70.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Expected number = P(blue) x total draws = 0.35 x 200 = 70.

questions.question_text: 1500 families were surveyed for the number of children: 0 children (210), 1 child (480), 2 children (540), 3+ children (270). The probability of a family having 2 children is:
If P(E) = 1, then event E is certain to occur.
questions.explanation_correct: P(E) = 1 means E occurs every time. It is a sure/certain event.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Probability 1 means the event is certain to happen.

questions.question_text: A bag has red, green, and yellow balls. In 300 draws with replacement, red appears 90 times and green 120 times. The experimental probability of yellow is:
An insurance company finds that 4 out of every 100 policyholders make a claim. The experimental probability that a policyholder will NOT make a claim is:
In 1000 throws of a die, 3 appeared 175 times. The experimental probability of NOT getting 3 is:
If the probability of an event is 0, the event is called an ___ event.
questions.explanation_correct: An event with probability 0 never occurs and is called an impossible event.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P(E) = 0 means the event is impossible.

questions.question_text: Three coins are tossed simultaneously 200 times. The results are: 3 heads (30), 2 heads (72), 1 head (68), 0 heads (30). The experimental probability of getting at least 2 heads is:
questions.explanation_correct: At least 2 heads means 2 or 3 heads. Frequency = 72 + 30 = 102. P(at least 2 heads) = 102/200 = 0.51.

questions.question_text: A die is thrown 600 times with outcomes: 1(100), 2(90), 3(115), 4(95), 5(80), 6(120). The experimental probability of getting a number greater than 4 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Numbers > 4 are 5 and 6. Frequency = 80 + 120 = 200. P(>4) = 200/600 = 1/3. Both A and C express the same value.

questions.question_text: If the experimental probability of defective bulbs is 0.02, how many defective bulbs are expected in a lot of 5000?
questions.explanation_correct: Expected defective = P(defective) x total = 0.02 x 5000 = 100.

questions.question_text: A student shoots at a target 250 times and hits it 175 times. The experimental probability of missing the target is:
questions.explanation_correct: Misses = 250 - 175 = 75. P(miss) = 75/250 = 3/10 = 0.3. Both B and C represent the same value.

questions.question_text: In a survey, 800 people were asked about their blood group. Results: A(320), B(200), AB(80), O(200). The experimental probability of blood group AB is ___.
Two coins are tossed 400 times. Results: 2 heads (110), 1 head (200), 0 heads (90). The experimental probability of getting at most one head is:
questions.explanation_correct: At most 1 head means 0 or 1 head. Frequency = 200 + 90 = 290. P(at most 1 head) = 290/400 = 0.725.

questions.question_text: The probability of event A is twice the probability of event B. If P(A) + P(B) = 0.9, then P(A) is:
In a weather study over 365 days: sunny(200), cloudy(100), rainy(65). The probability that a day is NOT rainy is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(not rainy) = (365-65)/365 = 300/365 = 60/73. Both B and C express the same value.

questions.question_text: If a die is thrown 6 times, each face must appear exactly once.
questions.explanation_correct: There is no guarantee that each face appears exactly once in 6 throws. The actual outcomes depend on chance. Any face could repeat or not appear at all.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dice throws are random. In 6 throws, any combination of outcomes is possible.

questions.question_text: In an experiment, the probabilities of outcomes A, B, C, D are 0.2, 0.3, 0.15, and p respectively. If these are the only outcomes, p is:
A bag contains balls of different colours. In 1000 draws (with replacement), the results are: White(200), Red(300), Blue(250), Green(250). The sum of the experimental probabilities of all colours is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(W)+P(R)+P(B)+P(G) = 200/1000 + 300/1000 + 250/1000 + 250/1000 = 1000/1000 = 1. The sum of all outcome probabilities is always 1.

questions.question_text: In a class of 50 students, the blood groups are: A(18), B(14), AB(8), O(10). If a student is chosen at random, the probability that the student does NOT have blood group B is:
questions.explanation_correct: P(not B) = (50-14)/50 = 36/50 = 18/25 = 0.72. Both A and C express the same value.
